dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: Apple Receives Rare Underperform Rating from Wall Street Analyst. Is It Time to Sell the Stock?
News Content: In a rare move, analysts at Jefferies downgraded one of the largest companies in the world, Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL), to underperform. Wall Street analysts are known for being bullish, so underperform and sell ratings tend to make up only a small percentage of overall analyst ratings.

For its part, Jefferies sees weak iPhone shipments in the fourth quarter, with Apple's artificial intelligence (AI) features not resonating with consumers. It cited a survey that most U.S. consumers do not find AI features very useful. As such, it thinks this is an indication that there will not be an AI power upgrade cycle for the iPhone.

Jefferies expects Apple to miss current analyst revenue estimates, calling for 5% growth when it reports its Q4 results at the end of January. It also thinks there is a good possibility Apple's Q1 guidance could disappoint as well. Its price target for the stock is $200.75.

Given the rare underperform rating, many investors may be wondering if it's time to sell the stock.

A strong business model

Despite the downgrade related to iPhone sales projections, one thing has not changed: Apple has a strong business model. The company's revenue growth was pretty lackluster throughout its fiscal 2024 ended in September. It only grew its revenue 2% on the year and 6% for its fiscal Q4. Revenue growth for its devices, meanwhile, has been even worse. Product revenue actually fell by 1% for its fiscal year, while rising by 4% last fiscal quarter.

Where Apple has seen stronger growth is in its high-margin services revenue. This includes revenue from its App Store, search-sharing revenue, Apple TV, Apple Pay, and other subscriptions and services. Last fiscal year, its services revenue climbed 13% and was up 12% in Q4.

Its services gross margin is close to 74%, while its product gross margin is about 37%. With the services margin nearly double, revenue coming from services more easily drops to bottom-line profits. As such, the company was able to grow its adjusted earnings per share by 11% last year to $6.75, despite only a 2% increase in revenue.Image source: Getty Images.

Right now, it appears that the big iPhone upgrade cycle related to Apple Intelligence is not materializing. The company has had some issues with its offering, such as its AI producing inaccurate news alerts. Meanwhile, both iPhone and Android smartphone users in surveys have indicated that that AI features are adding little to no value. Then there is the whole question of whether users will eventually pay for AI subscription services. Right now for Apple, AI seems to be more of a cost without any offsetting revenue benefit.

Story Continues

The company also hasn't been able to include Apple Intelligence with its smartphones in China. It had already been struggling in the country against local competitors, and according to Counterpoint Research, iPhone sales plunged in China by 18% in Q4. Sales of smartphones from rival Huawei, meanwhile, climbed 15.5% in the quarter.

Apple initially saw strong iPhone sales in China after it debuted its latest version. However, its AI is not approved in China and it must find a local AI partner to incorporate its technology to run Apple Intelligence in China. Apple mostly competes in the premium smartphone market in China, so the lack of the latest AI technology has left it behind competitors.

Outside of smartphone sales, Apple also faces another big risk related the Alphabet antitrust case. Alphabet has been paying Apple an estimated $20 billion a year as part of its revenue-sharing model for Google to be the default search engine for its browser Safari. This revenue is also virtually pure margin, dropping right to operating income. With Alphabet losing its antitrust case and this agreement in jeopardy, the impact it eventually could have on this revenue stream is still very much in the air as the case could lead to some pretty big changes. However, any impact is likely years away as the ruling gets appealed and both companies have reason to try to protect what is currently in place.

Expanding valuation

Apple stock has seen a lot of multiple expansion in the past several years. Its trailing price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio has essentially tripled from 12 times to 36 times, while its forward P/E based on current fiscal year estimates is around 30 times.AAPL PE Ratio (Forward) data by YCharts

Some of this multiple expansion can be attributed to the shift toward high-margin services revenue, as these businesses tend to carry higher multiples than hardware businesses. Apple has also proven to be a steady business that tends to have a somewhat predictable, albeit lengthening, replacement cycle.

That said, with the hope of an iPhone upgrade cycle diminishing and the stock seeing a lot of multiple expansion in the past six years, I think it would be smart to take some profits on the stock.

Don’t miss this second chance at a potentially lucrative opportunity

Ever feel like you missed the boat in buying the most successful stocks? Then you’ll want to hear this.

On rare occasions, our expert team of analysts issues a “Double Down” stock recommendation for companies that they think are about to pop. If you’re worried you’ve already missed your chance to invest, now is the best time to buy before it’s too late. And the numbers speak for themselves:

Nvidia:if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2009,you’d have $369,816!* Apple: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2008, you’d have $42,191!* Netflix: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2004, you’d have $527,206!*

Right now, we’re issuing “Double Down” alerts for three incredible companies, and there may not be another chance like this anytime soon.

Learn more »

*Stock Advisor returns as of January 21, 2025

Suzanne Frey, an executive at Alphabet, is a member of The Motley Fool’s board of directors. Geoffrey Seiler has positions in Alphabet. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Alphabet and Apple. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.

Apple Receives Rare Underperform Rating from Wall Street Analyst. Is It Time to Sell the Stock? was originally published by The Motley Fool

View Comments

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.2, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.8, Reasoning: The downgrade to an underperform rating from Jefferies significantly impacts investor sentiment, especially given Apple's recent struggles with iPhone sales, particularly in China. The lack of strong consumer interest in Apple's AI features and the potential for missing revenue expectations further exacerbates concerns. Moreover, Apple's strong services revenue and business model provide some cushioning, but the seismic shift in analyst ratings is more likely to prompt selling pressure than buying interest. Thus, there is a higher probability of the stock price declining based on this news.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.35, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.65, Reasoning: The news presents a mixed picture for Apple. A rare "underperform" rating from Jefferies, citing weak iPhone shipments due to unconvincing AI features and disappointing sales in China due to the lack of AI approval, is a significant negative signal. The price target of $200.75 suggests downside potential. The potential risk stemming from the Alphabet antitrust case is also a concern. However, Apple's strong services business with high margins provides a buffer. The existing high valuation (P/E ratio) makes the stock more vulnerable to negative news. The fact that revenue growth is primarily driven by services, masking weakness in product sales, suggests potential concerns about the long-term health of the core product business. Given these factors, the probability of a stock price fall is higher than a rise in the short-term. Note this is only short-term immediate impact, and a longer time horizon could yield different probabilities, as Apple has the potential for strong future growth. Given all positives and negatives, the estimation here errs on the side of caution. A news piece arguing to 'take some profits' on the stock usually indicates a short-term downward swing rather than further rapid ascent.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.5, Reasoning: The news presents a mixed outlook for Apple. While a rare underperform rating from Jefferies and concerns about weak iPhone shipments and AI feature adoption suggest potential downside, several counterarguments exist. Apple's strong services revenue growth, high margins, and historically resilient business model offer support.  The analyst's price target of $200.75 is still above the current price (context needed for precise comparison) which should temper immediate sell-offs.  The concerns about the Chinese market and the Alphabet antitrust case are significant long-term risks, but their immediate impact is uncertain. The article also mentions a multiple expansion in Apple's valuation which is a bearish factor. Considering this mix of positive and negative factors, a moderate probability of price fall is predicted, with a higher chance of price stability than a significant rise.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.7, Reasoning: The news highlights a rare underperform rating from Jefferies, citing weak iPhone shipments and lackluster consumer response to AI features, which could dampen investor sentiment. Additionally, challenges in China and potential risks from the Alphabet antitrust case add to the negative outlook. However, Apple's strong services revenue growth and high-margin business model provide some counterbalance. Given the rarity of such downgrades and the immediate negative sentiment, the short-term impact is likely negative, but the long-term resilience of Apple's business model may mitigate some of the downside.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.7, Reasoning: The news headline indicates that Apple Inc. (AAPL) received a rare underperform rating from Wall Street analyst Jefferies, citing weak iPhone shipments and disappointing revenue estimates. The analyst expects Apple's Q4 results and Q1 guidance to disappoint, and has set a price target of $200.75. Despite Apple's strong business model and growing services revenue, the downgrade and concerns about iPhone sales and AI features are likely to negatively impact the stock price. Additionally, the stock's high valuation with a forward P/E ratio of around 30 times and multiple expansion in the past few years make it vulnerable to a price correction. Therefore, the probability of the stock price falling is higher than rising.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.7, Reasoning: The analysis of the news article indicates that Apple Inc. has received a rare underperform rating from Wall Street analyst Jefferies due to weak iPhone shipment projections and a lack of consumer interest in the company's artificial intelligence features. The analyst expects Apple to miss current analyst revenue estimates and has set a price target of $200.75. However, the article also notes that Apple has a strong business model, with a growing services revenue segment that has a high gross margin. The company's valuation has expanded in recent years, with its forward price-to-earnings ratio around 30 times. Considering these factors, the probability of the stock price rising is lower than the probability of it falling due to the negative outlook from the analyst and the potential risks to the company's revenue and profitability.
Model: qwen/qwen-turbo, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.2, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.8, Reasoning: The financial news highlights a rare underperform rating from Jefferies, coupled with concerns over weak iPhone shipments, lack of AI feature resonance, and potential disappointments in revenue projections. Despite these negatives, Apple retains a strong business model with robust service revenue and solid margins. However, the negative sentiment from an analyst downgrade and specific concerns about future growth prospects suggest a bearish impact on investor sentiment.
Round: 1
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.25, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.75, Reasoning: The downgrade to an underperform rating from Jefferies denotes a significant shift in sentiment toward Apple, particularly given the noted concerns about weak iPhone shipments and lack of consumer interest in AI features. These factors, combined with the risk of missing revenue estimates and potential weaknesses in the Chinese market, contribute to a bearish outlook. Although Apple has a resilient business model supported by strong services revenue, the immediate impact of the downgrade and associated concerns is likely to raise selling pressure among investors. Consequently, I estimate a higher probability of the stock price falling compared to rising.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.25, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.75, Reasoning: The sentiment is overwhelmingly negative due to the 'underperform' rating, weak iPhone sales projections (especially in China due to AI limitations), and the potential impact of the Alphabet antitrust case on Apple's high-margin services revenue. However, Apple's strong business model, growing services revenue (though potentially threatened), and past performance provide *some* counterweight. The consistency of negative predictions (around 0.7-0.8 probability of falling) across previous rounds also reinforces this leans towards a negative sentiment here; especially seeing no new positive factor mentioned in the news report. The overall financial picture suggests a higher probability of a stock price decline.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.25, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.75, Reasoning: The news presents a mixed outlook for Apple.  The rare underperform rating from Jefferies, coupled with concerns about weak iPhone sales (especially in China due to AI limitations), and disappointing AI feature adoption, significantly weighs on the stock.  The $200.75 price target implies potential downside.  The Alphabet antitrust case presents a further long-term risk. However, Apple's robust and high-margin services business provides a counterbalance.  The high valuation (P/E ratio) makes it more sensitive to negative news.  The previous predictions show a consensus leaning towards a price drop, ranging from 0.65 to 0.8 probability.  Considering the immediate negative sentiment from the downgrade, the relatively high valuation, and the concerns about iPhone sales, the probability of a price fall is higher. I'm adjusting the probability slightly upward from the consensus due to Apple's strong service revenue and potential for long-term growth. However, the short-term outlook, given the present news, is more bearish.

Despite these negatives, Apple retains a strong business model with robust service revenue and solid margins. However, the negative sentiment from an analyst downgrade and specific concerns about future growth prospects suggest a bearish impact on investor sentiment. The potential revenue misses and complications in the Chinese market further accentuate this bearish outlook. While Apple's robust services model provides some cushioning, the immediate impact of the downgrade is likely to stimulate selling pressures. The consensus among previous predictions also heavily favors a likelihood of the stock price falling, as analysts pointed out various risks without considerable counterbalancing positives in the short term. The concerns about weak iPhone sales (especially in the critical Chinese market), lack of consumer adoption of AI features, and potential revenue misses significantly outweigh any positive aspects. While Apple's services revenue and business model are strong, the current environment and consistent bearish predictions across previous rounds reinforce the higher likelihood of a stock price decline. The failure to gain traction with AI and the risks from the Alphabet antitrust case add further downside potential, therefore, I will remain negative.

However, Apple's strong services segment and historically resilient nature temper this entirely negative assessment.

{ 
"reasoning": "[Summarize your analysis and reasoning process here]", 
"company_name": "[Company Name indicating the name of the company]", 
"company_symbol": "[Company Symbol indicating the stock symbol of the company]", 
"news_headline": "[News Headline indicating the provided financial news headline]",

} 
Do not generate output that isn't in properly formatted JSON.

```json
{
  "reasoning": "The news presents a mixed picture for Apple.  The significant negative is the rare 'underperform' rating from Jefferies, citing weak iPhone shipments, particularly due to disappointing AI features and struggles in the Chinese market.  This, combined with the potential for missed revenue estimates, strongly suggests downside pressure.  The analyst's price target of $200.75 implies further downward potential. The consistent bearish sentiment across multiple prediction rounds reinforces this negative outlook.  However, Apple's strong and high-margin services business offers a counterbalance, mitigating the potential for a drastic fall. The risk associated with the Alphabet antitrust case adds long-term uncertainty but doesn't significantly alter short-term expectations.  Considering the weight of negative factors, especially the analyst downgrade and the concerns about iPhone sales, the probability of a price fall is higher.  The strong services segment and Apple's historical resilience prevent a prediction of an extremely sharp decline, resulting in a moderate probability of a fall.",
```
